G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 28 authorizes this Court to modify any prior judgment for custody or visitation upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and a determination that the modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209, \u00a7 37.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209, § 37, and G.L. c. 215, § 3, as the original custody order was issued by this Court, the parties and the minor child reside in Massachusetts, and the matter concerns the custody and best interests of a Massachusetts child.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209, § 37, and G.L. c. 215, § 3, as the original custody order was issued by this Court, the parties and the minor child reside in Massachusetts, and the matter concerns the custody and best interests of a Massachusetts child.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior order, and that modification is in the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: This opinion is about an appeal from an initial custody judgment, focusing on the need for explicit findings regarding domestic violence and its effect on the child. It does not discuss the legal standard for *modifying* an existing custody order, nor does it reference the “material and substantial change in circumstances” requirement or G.L. c. 208, § 28. The case instead concerns the adequacy of findings supporting a current custody determination, so it does not provide authority for the modification standard stated in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior order, and that modification is in the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rolde v. Rolde is a direct appeal from an original divorce judgment that includes an initial custody determination; it does not concern a later request to modify an existing custody order. The court discusses the governing ‘best interests of the child’ standard for custody and evaluates the trial judge’s discretion, but it does not articulate or apply a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ test for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Thus, Rolde does not provide authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.proposition: The minor child’s developmental stage and her right to experience childhood free from undue parental caregiving burdens are significant factors the Court must consider when determining her best interests. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses best interests with a strong emphasis on stability, continuity with a primary caregiver, parents’ work schedules, and the child’s living arrangements, but it does not frame the analysis in terms of the child’s developmental stage or a right to be free from undue parental caregiving burdens. The court never articulates any principle that a child has a right to experience childhood without excessive caregiving responsibilities, nor does it analyze Kali’s developmental stage as an independent, significant factor. The cited pages mainly address preserving existing placements and proportional caretaking, not the proposition claimed.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.” (439 Mass. at 843)

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in any custody or visitation determination is the best interests of the child.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in any custody or visitation determination is the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 843.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that, under G.L. c. 208, § 30, the words “upon cause shown” mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child and further emphasizes that the best interests of the children are the paramount concern in deciding removal and related custody issues. The court’s analysis of custody and relocation is framed around the children’s best interests, directly supporting the proposition that this is the paramount consideration in such determinations under Massachusetts law.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 182\u20.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court has further held that, where modification of custody is sought, the Court must determine whether there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and whether the proposed modification will serve the child’s best interests. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–96; Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 182–83 (2006).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 182\u20.support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a custody‑modification case applying the two‑part “material and substantial change in circumstances” plus “best interests” test. The opinion does discuss best interests extensively, but it does not articulate or apply the threshold requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances for modification of custody. Using Mason as authority for that specific two‑step modification standard overstates what the case holds.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 182\u20.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.proposition: Factors relevant to the best-interests analysis include the child’s safety; the child’s emotional, mental, and physical needs; the stability of each home environment; and each parent’s ability to provide appropriate care. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 844–45; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (1998).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the best-interests determination between two prospective adoptive placements and the standard of appellate review; it does not set out or synthesize a general list of best-interest factors like safety, emotional/mental/physical needs, home stability, and parental ability in the way the proposition describes. While the court discusses Hugo’s special needs, the stability of each home, and the caretakers’ capacities, it does so fact-specifically and without announcing a general multi-factor test. Thus, citing this case as authority for the articulated factor list overstates what Hugo actually holds.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.relevant_excerpt: Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The “best interests of a child” is a question that presents the trial judge “with a classic example of a discretionary decision.” Adoption of a Minor (No. 2), 367 Mass. 684, 688 (1975). We recognize that in this field it is neither possible nor desirable to make decisions with precision, and that “much must be left to the trial judge’s experience and judgment.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 548\u2.proposition: Maintaining joint legal custody and a meaningful parenting relationship between Father and the minor child, while transitioning to primary physical custody with Mother, is consistent with Massachusetts law’s preference for continued parental involvement where appropriate and safe. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 548–49 (2010).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 548\u2.support_reasoning: The quoted concurring opinion in Smith v. McDonald is focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute (G.L. c. 209C) and the limits of a judge’s authority to order a custodial mother to relocate back to Massachusetts. It does not discuss, endorse, or analyze maintaining joint legal custody or a specific preference in Massachusetts law for continued involvement of both parents after a transition to primary physical custody with one parent. While it touches generally on stability and long‑distance visitation, it does not provide authority for the specific joint legal custody/continued parental involvement proposition claimed.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 548\u2.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. … Seen in light of the mother’s legitimate New York residence and the provisions of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), the distance separating the parties had relevance only as a factor in devising a reasonable long-distance visitation order ….”}

Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 510\u.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 28 authorizes this Court to modify any prior judgment for custody or visitation upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and a determination that the modification is in the best interests of the child. See also Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 510–11 (2013).
Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 510\u.support_reasoning: The opinion interprets G.L. c. 208, § 28 only with respect to modification of child support orders, not custody or visitation. The court in fact contrasts the statute’s prior use of the ‘material and substantial change’ standard for custody with the new ‘inconsistency’ standard for child support, and expressly states that § 28 continues to apply the material and substantial change standard only to custody, not to support. Thus, Morales does not support the proposition that § 28 authorizes modification of any custody or visitation judgment upon that standard; it addresses child support modification instead.
Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 510\u.relevant_excerpt: “Prior to its amendment in 1993 … § 28 provided that the material and substantial change standard was the correct standard for determining whether to modify a custody judgment or a child support order. … The 1993 amendment to § 28 clearly separated custody determinations from child support orders, applying the material and substantial change standard to modifications of custody orders and the inconsistency standard to modifications of child support orders. Compare § 28… (care and custody… ‘material and substantial change’) with § 28… (‘orders of maintenance and for support of minor children shall be modified if there is an inconsistency…’).”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 262 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a party seeking modification of custody bears the burden of demonstrating: (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (b) that the requested change is necessary in the child’s best interests. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–96; Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. at 182–83; Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 262 (2001).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G. L. c. 208, § 28 and describes the standard for modifying a prior custody judgment, stating that a modification judgment must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the modification must be necessary for the child’s welfare/best interests. The court reverses because no such qualifying change was shown. This aligns with the proposition that a party seeking modification of custody bears that dual burden.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555,.raw_text: Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555, 557–58 (1980)
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555,.proposition: The requested modification is consistent with the principle that custody and parenting-time orders are always subject to revision as the needs of the child and the capacities of the parents evolve over time. See Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555, 557–58 (1980); Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 402–03.
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555,.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize that custody determinations made in a divorce judgment are not immutable and may be changed upon a relevant change in circumstances, which is consistent with the broader principle that custody and parenting-time orders are subject to revision as circumstances evolve. The court states that the original custody judgment “was designed to endure until facts…should require a change” and that a transfer of custody requires a relevant change in circumstances. The case, however, is focused more narrowly on the standard for modifying custody (change in circumstances and best interests of the child) rather than expressly discussing ongoing evolution of parents’ capacities, so the support is indirect but real.
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555,.relevant_excerpt: “The original judgment awarding custody to Michele must be presumed to have been right. It settled all questions in issue between the parties at the time it was entered. It was designed to endure until facts brought to the attention of the court should require a change… To warrant a transfer of custody from one parent to another, following a determination of custody in a divorce proceeding, there must be a relevant change in circumstances.”

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The requested modification is further supported by the Court’s equitable powers under G.L. c. 215, § 6, allowing it to fashion orders necessary to protect the welfare of minor children subject to its jurisdiction.
